channel.title: Is this possible?
channel.description: I have been learning how to code in C# and was wondering if I should rewrite my server in C#. people tell me that C# is a more powerful language, so would this improve the capabilities of my server?

item.title: Is this possible?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:30, topic:517928”][quote author=Cres link=topic=636191.msg4296313#msg4296313 date=1368290656]

I hope you guys know that the server is not limited to Java just because the client is written in Java.

Yes, as there has been a lot of people here pointing that out.

Is Jagex’ servers written in Java or a native language like C++?

All I know is that it was all in Java initially.
They changed portions to C/C++ (I remember this from when they held a Q&A during a RuneTekk update).
EDIT: THE C/C++ changes were for the client. But the server being written in Java is true. I’m kinda certain they changed some parts of it by now though.
[/quote]
Jagex wrote the client in Java so it would work in browsers lol[/quote]

A significant portion of the codebase is in C/C++ for interfacing with DirectX, OpenGL, and other operating system-direct features. They also ported their own software rasterizer to native code to allow for faster rendering and more features to try and match the hardware accelerated renderers.

Afaik, they only ever confirmed their servers used Java and their own custom scripting language. I don’t really see any reason they’d have to move to native code, unless they wrote their own networking or threading libraries or something. There’s always the possibility their runescript interpreters are native, too. Overall, I think Java is perfectly suitable for handling runescape serverside.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

I hope you guys know that the server is not limited to Java just because the client is written in Java.

I’d only write the language which you find most comfortable (not forgetting limitations) because if your knowledge with C# is limited it would be a little harder to debug then using Java (for example).

Read full topic

item.title: Is this possible?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“A.L.P.O.H, post:1, topic:517928”]I have been learning how to code in C# and was wondering if I should rewrite my server in C#.
people tell me that C# is a more powerful language, so would this improve the capabilities of my server?[/quote]

‘More powerful’ usually indicates more features, not necessarily greater performance. C# definitely has more features than Java, but its speed comparisons are usually questionable. The runtime environments also work a lot differently. Java uses a Just-in-Time (JiT) native compiler to compile the most/longest used methods from bytecode to native code to enhance their speed, whereas .NET uses an Ahead of Time (AoT) compiler, which compiles most or all of the CIL bytecode to native code before executing. I’m not sure if .NET support JiT compilation or not. Which of these is better is actually quite a debate. It’s more complicated than is immediately obvious. There are pros and cons to both.

So if the runtime environments aren’t immediately comparable, then you have other considerations. Are the library functions more or less efficient than the other? More than likely they are equivalent, though you do want to consider whether the Java runtime environment you’re using binds a lot of its core API features to native code (which Oracle’s does). Microsoft’s .NET likely does the exact same. So decide first if you are using a lot of API-dependent code and, secondly, whether the equivalent code in C# is equally or more accelerated than the code you’re using in Java.

Next, do the API or language features in C# allow you to optimize your pipeline greater than that in Java? In some situations, this may be the case. It depends what I/O libraries you’re using and whether they require specific features of one language over the other (for all intended purposes, C# probably contains all the features of Java, but the converse is certainly not true).

Finally, you could decide to just accelerate the core code yourself by writing your own native libraries that directly communicate with POSIX or Win32 I/O functions. If that’s the case, there’s no need to even question whether to change languages because both C# and Java support native binding with C.

Only switch if you can deterministically know it will enhance the performance. If you’re not sure, port only the core code and write a test driver to benchmark the speeds between the C# and Java cores. Pick whichever is faster and stick with that language.

Read full topic

item.title: Is this possible?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Java isn’t built for speed anyways so it wouldn’t surprise me if the same server in another language would run faster.
Not going to say better because Java is pretty reliable.
Also, for a RS server, I think OO-programming is +/- a must. No idea if C# supports that since I haven’t looked into C# yet (and probably won’t for a long time).
If your only purpose is to make a faster server, try Lua or C.

Read full topic

item.title: Is this possible?
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

Lin:

From my experience when converting the 317 client to C#, the cache loading and unpacking and rendering is much faster in Java. I didn’t optimize anything, but I shouldn’t have had to for the file operations. C# can be pretty shitty, especially when it comes with arrays because it focuses on multi-dimensional arrays when jagged ones are significantly faster.

Surely C# has got both jagged and multi-dimensional ones.

Read full topic

item.title: Is this possible?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:14, topic:517928”][quote author=t4 link=topic=636191.msg4289285#msg4289285 date=1366926264]
You can write a server in any language that supports sockets. I’d suggest using a language you’re familiar with, though.
[/quote]

OMG OMG YOU MESSED UP SO BADLY NOW. A LANGUAGE DOES NOT SUPPORT SOCKETS, THE LIBRARIES DO. OMG U STOOPID T4.-[/quote]
Well, most languages have sockets in their standard libraries. C and C++ don’t so I guess you got me there you sly fox. I would consider the standard library apart of the language (assuming we’re not talking about grammars and whatnot).

Read full topic
